abstract.p: Richard A Plunz letter comments on May 25 article on the architect Richard Meier

block.p: The article ''Richard Meier Builds in Manhattan. At Last.'' (May 25) gives the impression that, apart from Westbeth, Mr. Meier's practice was devoid of New York City commissions, unless New York City is defined only as Manhattan.

The article ''Richard Meier Builds in Manhattan. At Last.'' (May 25) gives the impression that, apart from Westbeth, Mr. Meier's practice was devoid of New York City commissions, unless New York City is defined only as Manhattan.

The first large commission in Richard Meier's career was in the Bronx for the 523-apartment Twin Parks Northeast housing project, completed in 1973. This lapse of memory is notable, especially given the notoriety of the project, with its contextural innovations and its social problems. Then, there was the massive Bronx Developmental Center, completed by Mr. Meier in 1976 with wide publicity.

Indirectly, your article underlines the architectural profession's critical amnesia insofar as its production is concerned. One can only reflect on the meaning of Mr. Meier's current desire for a ''next phase, a phase that will deal with urban issues.''
RICHARD A. PLUNZ Professor of architecture, Director, Urban Design Program, Columbia University New York
